FedFed: Feature Distillation against Data Heterogeneity in Federated Learning

Zhiqin Yang1 â€ƒYonggang Zhang2âˆ— â€ƒYu Zheng3 â€ƒXinmei Tian5 â€ƒ
Hao Peng1,6 â€ƒTongliang Liu4 â€ƒBo Han2 â€ƒ
1Beihang University â€ƒ2Hong Kong Baptist University â€ƒ3Chinese University of Hong Kong
4The University of Sydney â€ƒ5University of Science and Technology of China

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) typically faces data heterogeneity, i.e., distribution shifting among clients. Sharing clientsâ€™ information has shown great potentiality in mitigating data heterogeneity, yet incurs a dilemma in preserving privacy and promoting model performance. To alleviate the dilemma, we raise a fundamental question: Is it possible to share partial features in the data to tackle data heterogeneity? In this work, we give an affirmative answer to this question by proposing a novel approach called Federated Feature distillation (FedFed). Specifically, FedFed partitions data into performance-sensitive features (i.e., greatly contributing to model performance) and performance-robust features (i.e., limitedly contributing to model performance). The performance-sensitive features are globally shared to mitigate data heterogeneity, while the performance-robust features are kept locally. FedFed enables clients to train models over local and shared data. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the efficacy of FedFed in promoting model performance. The code is available at https://github.com/visitworld123/FedFed.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL), beneficial for training over multiple distributed data sources, has recently received increasing attentionÂ (kairouz2021advances, ; li2021survey, ; yang2019federated, ). In FL, many clients collaboratively train a global model by aggregating gradients (or model parameters) without the need to share local data. However, the major concern is heterogeneity issuesÂ (mcmahan2017communication, ; li2022federated, ; li2020federated, ) caused by Non-IID distribution of distributed data and diverse computing capability across clients. The heterogeneity issues can cause unstable model convergence and degraded prediction accuracy, hindering further FL deployments in practiceÂ (kairouz2021advances, ).

To address the heterogeneity challenge, the seminal work, federated averaging (FedAvg), introduces the model aggregation of locally trained modelsÂ (mcmahan2017communication, ). It addresses the diversity of computing and communication but still faces the issue of client drift induced by data heterogeneityÂ (karimireddy2020scaffold, ). Therefore, a branch of works for defending data heterogeneity has been explored by devising new learning objectivesÂ (li2020federated, ), aggregation strategiesÂ (yurochkin2019bayesian, ), and constructing shareable information across clientsÂ (zhao2018federated, ). Among explorations as aforementioned, sharing clientsâ€™ information has been considered to be a straightforward and promising approach to mitigate data heterogeneityÂ (zhao2018federated, ; luo2021no, ).

However, the dilemma of preserving data privacy and promoting model performance hinders the practical effectiveness of the information-sharing strategy. Specifically, it shows that a limited amount of shared data could significantly improve model performanceÂ (zhao2018federated, ). Unfortunately, no matter for sharing raw data, synthesized data, logits, or statistical informationÂ (luo2021no, ; goetz2020federated, ; hao2021towards, ; karimireddy2020scaffold, ) can incur privacy concernsÂ (nasr2019comprehensive, ; mothukuri2021survey, ; yan2022membership, ). Injecting random noise to data provides provable security for protecting privacyÂ (dppaper, ; du2023dpforward, ). Yet, the primary concern for applying noise to data lies in performance degradationÂ (tramer2020differentially, ) as the injected noise negatively contributes to model performance. Thus, perfectly playing the role of shared information requires tackling the dilemma of data privacy and model performance.

We revisit the purpose of sharing information to alleviate the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements and ask:

Q.1 Is it possible to share partial features in the data to mitigate heterogeneity in FL? This question is fundamental to reaching a new phase for mitigating heterogeneity with the information-sharing strategy. Inspired by the partition strategy of spurious feature and robust feature (zhang2021adversarial, ), the privacy and performance dilemma could be solved if the data features were separated into performance-robust and performance-sensitive parts without overlapping, where the performance-robust features contain almost all the information in the data. Namely, the performance-robust features that limitedly contribute to model performance are kept locally. Meanwhile, the performance-sensitive features that could contribute to model generalization are selected to be shared across clients. Accordingly, the server can construct a global dataset using the shared performance-sensitive features, which enables clients to train their models over the local and shared data.

Q.2 How to divide data into performance-robust features and performance-sensitive features? The question is inherently related to the spirit of the information bottleneck (IB) methodÂ (IB0, ). In IB, ideal features should discard all information in data features except for the minimal sufficient information for generalizationÂ (IB, ). Concerning the information-sharing and performance-improvement dilemma, the features discarded in IB may contain performance-robust features, i.e., private information, thus, they are unnecessary to be shared for heterogeneity mitigation. Meanwhile, the performance-sensitive features contain information for generalization, which are the minimum sufficient information and should be shared across clients for heterogeneity mitigation. Therefore, IB provides an information-theoretic perspective of dividing data features for heterogeneity mitigation in FL.

Q.3 What if performance-sensitive features contain private information? This question lies in the fact that a non-trivial information-sharing strategy should contain necessary data information to mitigate the issue of data heterogeneity. That is, the information-sharing strategy unavoidably causes privacy risks. Fortunately, we can follow the conventional style in applying random noise to protect performance-sensitive features because the noise injection approach can provide a de facto standard way for provable securityÂ (dppaper, ). Notably, applying random noise to performance-sensitive features differs from applying random noise for all data features. More specifically, sharing partial features in the data is more accessible to preserve privacy than sharing complete data features, which is fortunately consistent with our theoretical analysis, see Theorem 3.3 in Sec. 3.3.

Our Solution. Built upon the above analysis, we propose a novel framework, named Federated Feature distillation (FedFed), to tackle data heterogeneity by generating and sharing performance-sensitive features. According to the question Q.1, FedFed introduces a competitive mechanism by decomposing data features ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with dimension dğ‘‘d into performance-robust features ğ±râˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{r}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and performance-sensitive features ğ±sâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ±ğ‘ superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{s}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, i.e., ğ±=ğ±r+ğ±sğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{r}+\mathbf{x}_{s}. Then following the question Q.1, FedFed generates performance-robust features ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} in an IB manner for data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. In line with Q.1, FedFed enables clients to securely share their protected features ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p} by applying random noise ğ§ğ§\mathbf{n} to performance sensitive features ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}, i.e., ğ±p=ğ±s+ğ§subscriptğ±ğ‘subscriptğ±ğ‘ ğ§\mathbf{x}_{p}=\mathbf{x}_{s}+\mathbf{n}, where ğ§ğ§\mathbf{n} is drawn from a Gaussian distribution ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,Ïƒs2â€‹ğˆ)ğ’©0subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘ ğˆ\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}_{s}\mathbf{I}) with variance Ïƒs2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘ \sigma^{2}_{s}. Finally, the server can construct a global dataset to tackle data heterogeneity using the protected features ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p}, enabling clients to train models over the local private and globally shared data.

We deploy FedFed on four popular FL algorithms, including FedAvgÂ (mcmahan2017communication, ), FedProxÂ (li2020federated, ), SCAFFOLDÂ (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and FedNovaÂ (wang2020tackling, ). Atop them, we conduct comprehensive experiments on various scenarios regarding different amounts of clients, varying degrees of heterogeneity, and four datasets. Extensive results show that the FedFed achieves considerable performance gains in all settings.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We pose a foundation question to challenge the necessity of sharing all data features for mitigating heterogeneity in FL with information-sharing strategies. The question sheds light on solving the privacy and performance dilemma, in a way of sharing partial features that contribute to data heterogeneity mitigation (SecÂ 3.1)

  2. 2.

    To solve the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements, we propose a new framework FedFed. In FedFed, each client performs feature distillationâ€”partitioning local data into performance-robust and performance-sensitive features (SecÂ 3.2) â€”and shares the latter with random noise globally (SecÂ 3.3). Consequently, FedFed can mitigate data heterogeneity by enabling clients to train their models over the local and shared data.

  3. 3.

    We conduct comprehensive experiments to show that FedFed consistently and significantly enhances the convergence rate and generalization performance of FL models across different scenarios (SecÂ 4.2).

Differential Privacy. Differential privacyÂ (dppaper, ) is a framework to quantify to what extent individual privacy in a dataset is preserved while releasing the data.

Definition 2.1.

(Differential Privacy). In sum, DP as a de facto standard of quantitative privacy, provides provable security for protecting privacy.

Information Bottleneck. Traditionally, in the context of the Information Bottleneck (IB) framework, the goal is to effectively capture the information relevant to the output label Yğ‘ŒY, denoted as Zğ‘Z, while simultaneously achieving maximum compression of the input Xğ‘‹X. Zğ‘Z represents the latent embedding, which serves as a compressed and informative representation of Xğ‘‹X, preserving the essential information while minimizing redundancy. This objective can be formulated as:

â„’ğ–¨ğ–¡=Iâ€‹(X;Y|Z),s.t.Iâ€‹(X;Z)â‰¤Iğ–¨ğ–¡formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„’ğ–¨ğ–¡ğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ–¨ğ–¡\mathcal{L}_{\mathsf{IB}}=I(X;Y|Z),\quad s.t.\ I(X;Z)\leq I_{\mathsf{IB}} (4)

where Iâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¼â‹…I(\cdot) denote the mutual information and Iğ–¨ğ–¡subscriptğ¼ğ–¨ğ–¡I_{\mathsf{IB}} is a constant. This function is defined as a rate-distortion problem, indicating that IB is to extract the most efficient and informative features.

3 Methodology

We detail the Federated Feature distillation (FedFed) proposed to mitigate data heterogeneity in FL. FedFed adopts the information-sharing strategy with the spirits of information bottleneck (IB). Roughly, it shares the minimal sufficient features, while keeping other features at clients111AppendixÂ A displays FedFedâ€™s overview. .

3.1 Motivation

Data heterogeneity inherently comes from the difference in data distribution among clients. Aggregating models without accessing data would inevitably bring performance degradation. Sharing clientsâ€™ data benefits model performance greatly, but intrinsically violates privacy.

Applying DP to protect shared data looks feasible; however, it is not a free lunch with paying the accuracy loss on the model.

Draw inspiration from the content and style partition of data causesÂ (zhang2021adversarial, ), we investigate the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements through a feature partition perspective. By introducing an appropriate partition, we can share performance-sensitive features while keeping performance-robust features locally. Namely, performance-sensitive features in the data are all we need for mitigating data heterogeneity!

We will elucidate the definitions of performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features. Firstly, we provide a precise definition of a valid partition (DefinitionÂ 3.1), which captures the desirable attributes when partitioning features. Subsequently, adhering to the rules of a valid partition, we formalize the two types of features (DefinitionÂ 3.2).

Definition 3.1.

(Valid Partition). A partition strategy is to partition a variable Xğ‘‹X into two parts in the same measure space such that X=X1+X2ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹2X=X_{1}+X_{2}. We say the partition strategy is valid if it holds: (i) Hâ€‹(X1,X2|X)=0ğ»subscriptğ‘‹1conditionalsubscriptğ‘‹2ğ‘‹0H(X_{1},X_{2}|X)=0; (ii) Hâ€‹(X|X1,X2)=0ğ»conditionalğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹20H(X|X_{1},X_{2})=0; (iii) Iâ€‹(X1;X2)=0ğ¼subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹20I(X_{1};X_{2})=0; where Hâ€‹(â‹…)ğ»â‹…H(\cdot) denotes the information entropy and Iâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¼â‹…I(\cdot) is the mutual information.

Definition 3.2.

(Performance-sensitive and Performance-robust Features). Let X=Xs+Xrğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ŸX=X_{s}+X_{r} be a valid partition strategy. We say Xssubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ X_{s} are performance-sensitive features such that Iâ€‹(X;Y|Xs)=0ğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ 0I(X;Y|X_{s})=0, where Yğ‘ŒY is the label of Xğ‘‹X. Accordingly, Xrsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ŸX_{r} are the performance-robust features.

Intuitively, performance-sensitive features contain all label information, while performance-robust features contain all information about the data except for the label information. More discussions about DefinitionÂ 3.1 and DefinitionÂ 3.2 can be found in AppendixÂ C.1. Now, the challenge turns out to be: Can we derive performance-sensitive features to mitigate data heterogeneity? FedFed provides an affirmative answer from an IB perspective, boosting a simple yet effective data-sharing strategy.

3.2 Feature Distillation

Given the motivation above, we propose to distil features such that data features can be partitioned into performance-robust features depicting mostly data and performance-sensitive features favourable to model performance. We design feature distillation and answer Q.1 below.

We draw inspiration from the information bottleneck methodÂ (IB, ). Specifically, only minimal sufficient information is preserved in learned representations while the other features are dismissedÂ (IB, ). This can be formulated asÂ 222We follow the formulation used in Tishby and Zaslavsky (IB, ; tishby2015deep, ).:

minZâ¡Iâ€‹(X;Y|Z),s.t.â€‹Iâ€‹(X;Z)â‰¤Iğ–¨ğ–¡,subscriptğ‘ğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘s.t.ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ–¨ğ–¡\min_{Z}I(X;Y|Z),\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X;Z)\leq I_{\mathsf{IB}}, (5)

where Zğ‘Z represents the desired representation extracted from input Xğ‘‹X with its label Yğ‘ŒY, Iâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¼â‹…I(\cdot) is the mutual information, and Iğ–¨ğ–¡subscriptğ¼ğ–¨ğ–¡I_{\mathsf{IB}} stands for a constant. Namely, given the learned representation Zğ‘Z, the mutual information between Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY is minimized. Meanwhile, Zğ‘Z dismisses most information about the input Xğ‘‹X so that the mutual information Iâ€‹(X;Z)ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘I(X;Z) is less than a constant Iğ–¨ğ–¡subscriptğ¼ğ–¨ğ–¡I_{\mathsf{IB}}.

Similarly, in FedFed, only minimal sufficient information is necessary to be shared across clients to mitigate data heterogeneity, while the other features are dismissed before sharing data, i.e., kept locally on the client. The differences between IB and FedFed have two folds: 1) FedFed aims to make the dismissed features close to the original features (i.e., depict most private data information), while IB focuses on the dissimilarity between the preserved and original features (i.e., contain minimal sufficient information about data); 2) FedFed dismisses information in the data space while IB does that in the representation space. More specifically, the objective of feature distillation is:

minZâ¡Iâ€‹(X;Y|Z),s.t.â€‹Iâ€‹(X;Xâˆ’Z|Z)â‰¥Iğ–¥ğ–¥,subscriptğ‘ğ¼ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘Œğ‘s.t.ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘‹conditionalğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ–¥ğ–¥\min_{Z}{I(X;Y|Z)},\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X;X-Z|Z)\geq I_{\mathsf{FF}}, (6)

where Zğ‘Z represents the performance-sensitive features in Xğ‘‹X, Yğ‘ŒY is the label of Xğ‘‹X, (Xâˆ’Z)ğ‘‹ğ‘(X-Z) stands for performance-robust features that are unnecessary to be shared, and Iğ–¥ğ–¥subscriptğ¼ğ–¥ğ–¥I_{\mathsf{FF}} is a constant. In Eq. (6), the (Xâˆ’Z)ğ‘‹ğ‘(X-Z) should represent data mostly conditioned on performance-sensitive features Zğ‘Z, while the Zğ‘Z should contain necessary information about the label Yğ‘ŒY. Consequently, learning with the objective can divide data features into performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features, achieving the goal of feature distillation.

To make the feature distillation tractable, we derive an objective equal to the original objective in Eq. (6) (see Appendix C.2 for more details) for client kğ‘˜k as follows:

Thus, by Eq. 8, performance-sensitive features can predict labels and performance-robust features are almost the same as raw features.

AlgorithmÂ 1 summarizes the procedure of feature distillation.

3.3 Protection for Performance-Sensitive Features

Until now, we have intentionally overlooked the overlap between performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features. Since we prioritize data heterogeneity, overlapping is almost unavoidable in practice, i.e., performance-sensitive features containing certain data privacy. Accordingly, merely sharing performance-sensitive features can risk privacy. Thus, we answer Q.Â 1 below.

Why employ DP? The constructed performance-sensitive features may contain individual privacy, thus, the goal of introducing a protection approach is for individual privacy. In addition, the employed protection approach is expected to be robust against privacy attacksÂ (sp/ShokriSSS17, ; uss/0001TO21, ). According to the above analysis, differential privacy (DP) is naturally suitable in our scenario of feature distillation. Thus, we employ DP to protect performance-sensitive features before sending them to the server.

How to apply DP? Applying noise (e.g., Gaussian or Laplacian) to performance-sensitive features before sharing can protect features with DP guaranteeÂ (stoc/BlumLR08, ; dppaper, ), i.e., ğ±p=ğ±s+ğ§subscriptğ±ğ‘subscriptğ±ğ‘ ğ§\mathbf{x}_{p}=\mathbf{x}_{s}+\mathbf{n}. Consequently, the server can collect protected features ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p} from clients to construct a global dataset and send the dataset back to clients. To give a vivid illustration, we provide a guessing game333We reveal the answer in AppendixÂ F.2 in FigureÂ 1, showing 444 images. The first image represents the DP-protected performance-sensitive features of one image (A, B, or C). It is hard to identify which one of the raw images (A, B, C) the first image belongs to.

Training with DP. The protected performance-sensitive features are shared, thus, the server can construct a globally shared dataset. Using the global dataset, clients can train local classifier fâ€‹(â‹…;Ï•k)ğ‘“â‹…subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜f(\cdot;\phi_{k}) parameterized by Ï•ksubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜\phi_{k} with the private and shared data:

minÏ•kâ¡ğ”¼(ğ±,ğ²)âˆ¼Pâ€‹(Xk,Yk)â€‹â„“â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±;Ï•k),ğ²)+ğ”¼(ğ±p,ğ²)âˆ¼Pâ€‹(ğ¡â€‹(Xk),Yk)â€‹â„“â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±p;Ï•k),ğ²),subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ²ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â„“ğ‘“ğ±subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜ğ²subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ±ğ‘ğ²ğ‘ƒğ¡subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â„“ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜ğ²\begin{split}\min_{\phi_{k}}\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y})+\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x}_{p},\mathbf{y})\sim P(\mathbf{h}(X_{k}),Y_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x}_{p};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y}),\end{split} (10)

where fâ€‹(â‹…;Ï•k)ğ‘“â‹…subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜f(\cdot;\phi_{k}) is trained for model aggregation, (ğ±p,ğ²)subscriptğ±ğ‘ğ²(\mathbf{x}_{p},\mathbf{y}) are protected performance-sensitive features that are collected from all clients, and ğ¡â€‹(Xk):=ğ³â€‹(Xk)+nassignğ¡subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜ğ³subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜ğ‘›\mathbf{h}(X_{k}):=\mathbf{z}(X_{k})+n with noise nğ‘›n. Pseudo-code of how to apply FedFed are listed in AppendixÂ B.

DP guarantee. Following DP-SGDÂ abadi2016deep , we employ the idea of the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm clipping relating to the selection of the noise level Ïƒğœ\sigma. Specifically, we realize the constraint in Eq. (9) as follows: â€–ğ³â€‹(ğ±;Î¸)â€–2â‰¤Ïâ€‹â€–ğ±â€–subscriptnormğ³ğ±ğœƒ2ğœŒnormğ±\|\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)\|_{2}\leq\rho\|\mathbf{x}\|, with 0<Ï<10ğœŒ10<\rho<1 (i.e., â€–ğ±sâ€–â‰¤Ïâ€‹â€–ğ±â€–normsubscriptğ±ğ‘ ğœŒnormğ±\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|\leq\rho\|\mathbf{x}\|). For aligning analyses with conventional DP guarantee, we let the random mechanism on performance-robust features ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} be ğ±r+n,nâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒr2â€‹ğˆ)similar-tosubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿğ‘›ğ‘›ğ’©0superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘Ÿ2ğˆ\mathbf{x}_{r}+n,n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{r}^{2}\mathbf{I}). Similar for performance-sensitive features, we have ğ±s+n,nâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒs2â€‹ğˆ)similar-tosubscriptğ±ğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ’©0superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ 2ğˆ\mathbf{x}_{s}+n,n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{s}^{2}\mathbf{I}). Since ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} is kept locally, an adversary views nothing (or random data without any entropy). This keeps equal to adding a sufficiently large noise, i.e., Ïƒr=âˆsubscriptğœğ‘Ÿ\sigma_{r}=\infty on ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} to make it random enough. Consequently, FedFed can provide a strong privacy guarantee. Moreover, for each client, we show that FedFed requires a relatively small noise level Ïƒğœ\sigma for achieving identical privacy, which is given in TheoremÂ 3.3 (detailed analysis is left in AppendixÂ D).

Theorem 3.3.

Let Ïƒğœ\sigma be the noise scale for FedFed and Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} be the noise scale for sharing raw ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. Besides each client, we give the privacy analysis for the FL system paired with the proposed FedFed.

Atop composition theoremÂ icml/KairouzOV15 , TheoreomÂ 3.4 shows that FedFed is able to provide a strong privacy guarantee for FL systems.

4 Experiments

We organize this section in the following aspects: a) the main experimental settings that we primarily followed (SecÂ 4.1); b) the main results and observations of applying FedFed to existing popular FL algorithms (SecÂ 4.2); c) the sensitivity study of hyper-parameters on effecting model performance (SecÂ 4.3); and d) empirical analysis of privacy with two kinds of attacks (SecÂ 4.4).

4.1 Experimental Setup

Federated Non-IID Datasets. Following previous worksÂ (luo2021no, ; zhang2022federated, ), we conduct experiments over CIFAR-10, CIFAR100Â (krizhevsky2009learning, ), Fashion-MNIST(FMNIST)Â (xiao2017fashion, ), and SVHNÂ (netzer2011reading, ). FollowingÂ (li2022federated, ), we employ latent Dirichlet sampling (LDA)Â (hsu2019measuring, ) to simulate Non-IID distribution. In our experiments, followingÂ (li2022federated, ; vhl, ), we set Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 and Î±=0.05ğ›¼0.05\alpha=0.05 by LDA.

Besides, we evaluate FedFed with other two widely adopted partition strategies: #â€‹C=k#ğ¶ğ‘˜\#C=kÂ (mcmahan2017communication, ; li2022federated, ) and Subset methodÂ (zhao2018federated, ), mainly including label skew and quantity skew (AppendixÂ F.1 shows more detail of data distribution).

Models, Metrics and Baselines. We use ResNet-18Â (he2016deep, ) both in the feature distillation and classifier in FL. We evaluate the model performance via two popular metrics in FL: a) communication rounds and b) best accuracy. Typically, the target accuracy is set to be the best accuracy of vanilla FedAvg. As a plug-in approach, we apply FedFed to prevailing existing FL algorithms, such as FedAvgÂ (mcmahan2017communication, ), FedProxÂ (li2020federated, ), SCAFFOLDÂ (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and FedNovaÂ (wang2020tackling, ) to compare the efficiency of our method. More experimental settings and details are listed in AppendixÂ B.1.

4.2 Main Results

Generative Model Selection. We consider two generative models in this paper to distill raw data, i.e., Resnet Generator, a kind of vanilla generator used in many worksÂ (zhu2017unpaired, ; poursaeed2018generative, ), and Î²ğ›½\beta-VAEÂ (higgins2016beta, ), an encoder-decoder structure by variational inference. We verify the effectiveness of FedFed with different generative models. According to results shown in FigureÂ 2 (a), we observe that Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE gets better performance in FedFed. Thus, we mainly report the results of Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE in the rest.

Result Analysis. The experimental results on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, FMNIST, and SVHN are shown respectively in TablesÂ 1, 2, 3, and 4. It can be seen that the proposed method can consistently and significantly improve model accuracy under various settings. Moreover, FedFed can promote the convergence rate of different algorithms444 More supporting figures of convergence rate are moved to appendixÂ F.4. Specifically, FedFed brings significant performance gain in CIFAR-10 under the K=100ğ¾100K=100 setting shown in TableÂ 1 and also notably speeds up the convergence rate in FMNIST under the Î±=0.05,E=1,K=10formulae-sequenceğ›¼0.05formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğ¾10\alpha=0.05,E=1,K=10 setting. However, attributable to the original FL methods almost reaching a performance bottleneck, FedFed achieves limited performance gain in SVHN and FMNIST. FedFed also has limited improvement in CIFAR-100. A possible reason is that existing methods can achieve performance comparable to centralized training. Moreover, we conducted an additional experiment involving sharing the full data with DP protection. The results, presented in AppendixÂ F.3, indicate that sharing the full data with DP protection leads to a degradation in the performance of the FL system. This degradation occurs because protecting the full data necessitates a relatively large noise to achieve the corresponding protection strength required to safeguard performance-sensitive features.

Surprising Observations. We find that training among 100100100 clients in CIFAR-10 and CIFAR100 reaches a significant improvement (e.g., at most 40.67%percent40.6740.67\%!). A possible reason is that the missed data knowledge can be well replenished by FedFed. Moreover, all methods paired with FedFed under various settings can achieve similar prediction accuracies, demonstrating that FedFed endows FL models robustness against data heterogeneity. TableÂ 6 shows that two kinds of heterogeneity partition cause more performance decline than LDA (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1). Yet, FedFed attains noteworthy improvement, indicating the robustness against Non-IID partition.

4.3 Ablation Study

DP Noise. To explore the relationship between privacy level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and prediction accuracy, we conduct experiments with different noise levels Ïƒs2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ 2\sigma_{s}^{2}. As shown in FigureÂ 2(c), the prediction accuracy decreases with increasing noise level (more results in AppendixÂ F.5). To verify whether the FedFed is robust against the selection of noise, we also consider Laplacian noise in applying DP to privacy protection. The results of Laplacian noise are reported in TableÂ 6, demonstrating the robustness of FedFed.

Hyper-parameters. We further evaluate the robustness of FedFed against hyper-parameters. During the feature distillation process, as the constraint parameter ÏğœŒ\rho in Eq.Â 9 decreases, the DP strength to protect performance-sensitive features decreases, and the performance of the global model decreases, owing to the less information contained in performance-sensitive features.

4.4 Privacy Verification

Besides the theoretical analysis, we provide empirical analysis to support the privacy guarantee of FedFed. We wonder whether the globally shared data can be inferred by some attacking methods. Thus, we resort to model inversion attackÂ (he2019model, ), widely used in the literature to reconstruct data. The results555More details and results can be found in AppendixÂ E.1. in FigureÂ 3 (a) and (b) indicate that FedFed could protect globally shared data. We also conduct another model inversion attackÂ (zhang2020secret, ) and the results can be found in AppendixÂ E.1. Additionally, we perform membership inference attackÂ (shokri2017membership, ) to illustrate the difference between FedFed and sharing all data features with DP protection. The results illustrated in FigureÂ 3 (c) show that noise level Ïƒ2=0.3superscriptğœ20.3\sigma^{2}=0.3 over raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} can achieve similar protection as noise Ïƒs2=0.15superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ 20.15\sigma_{s}^{2}=0.15 over globally shared data ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p}, which aligns with TheoremÂ 3.3. More details can be found in AppendixÂ E.2

5 Related Work

Federated Learning (FL) models typically perform poorly when meeting severe Non-IID dataÂ (li2021survey, ; karimireddy2020scaffold, ). To tackle data heterogeneity, advanced works introduce various learning objectives to calibrate the updated direction of local training from being far away from the global model, e.g., FedProx(li2020federated, ), FedIRÂ (hsu2020federated, ), SCAFFOLDÂ (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and MOONÂ (li2021model, ). Designing model aggregation schemes like FedAvgMÂ (hsu2019measuring, ), FedNovaÂ (wang2020tackling, ), FedMAÂ (wang2020federated, ), and FedBNÂ (li2021fedbn, ) shows the efficacy on heterogeneity mitigation. Another promising direction is the information-sharing strategy, which mainly focuses on synthesizing and sharing clientsâ€™ information to mitigate heterogeneityÂ (zhao2018federated, ; jeong2018communication, ; long2021g, ). To avoid exposing privacy caused by the shared data, some methods utilize the statistics of dataÂ (shin2020xor, ), representations of dataÂ (hao2021towards, ), logitsÂ (chang2019cronus, ; luo2021no, ), embeddingÂ (tan2022fedproto, ). However, advanced attacks pose potential threats to methods with data-sharing strategiesÂ (zhao2020makes, ).

FedFed is inspired byÂ (vhl, ), where pure noise is shared across clients to tackle data heterogeneity. In this work, we relax the privacy concern by sharing partial features in the data with DP protection. In addition, our work is technically similar to an adversarial learning approachÂ (yang2021class, ). Our method distinguishes by defining various types of features and delving into the exploration of data heterogeneity within FL. More discussion can be found in AppendixÂ G.

6 Conclusion

In this work, we propose a novel framework, called FedFed, to tackle data heterogeneity in FL by employing the promising information-sharing approach. Our work extends the research line of constructing shareable information of clients by proposing to share partial features in data. This shares a new route of improving training performance and maintaining privacy in the meantime. Furthermore, FedFed has served as a source of inspiration for a new direction focused on improving performance in open-set scenariosÂ (fang2022out, ). Another avenue of exploration involves deploying FedFed in other real-time FL application scenarios, such as recommendation systemsÂ (liu2022federated, ) and medical image analysisÂ (zhou2022sparse, ), to uncover its potential benefits.

Limitation. Limited local hardware resources may limit the power of FedFed, since FedFed introduces some extra overheads like communication overheads and storage overheads. We leave it as future work to explore a hardware-friendly version. Additionally, FedFed raises potential privacy concerns that we leave as a future research exploration, such as integrating cryptographyÂ sp/NgC23 . We anticipate that our work will inspire further investigations to comprehensively evaluate the privacy risks associated with information-sharing strategies aimed at mitigating data heterogeneity.

Supplementary Material for FedFed: Feature Distillation against Data Heterogeneity in Federated Learning

Appendix A Overview of FedFed Framework

The training process of the federated learning system with FedFed can be summarized into four phases. Firstly, every participant of FL distils the local private raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} and decouples ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} into performance-robust features ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} and performance-sensitive features ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} during the feature distillation phase. Then all clients send ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p} to construct a global dataset, ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} with DP protection and keep ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} locally. In the local training phase, the selected clients sample a subset from the globally shared dataset and update the local model with local raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} and sampled information ğ±psubscriptğ±ğ‘\mathbf{x}_{p} from server. Finally, clients upload the latest local model and aggregate a global model based on a certain aggregation algorithm, like the weighted average strategy in FedAvg. FigureÂ 4 shows the overview of FedFed framework, while FigureÂ 5 depicts its pipeline of feature distillation. The loss function of feature distillation in FigureÂ 5 is EqÂ (9).

Whereas, we use 0.01 as the learning rate. In our work, we deploy FedFed on SCAFFOLD and set the learning rate Î·ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta_{k} to 0.0001 for the SVHN dataset. Furthermore, we use Î·k=0.001subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜0.001\eta_{k}=0.001 in SVHN while FedNove is deployed with our method.

The batch size is set as 64 when K=10ğ¾10K=10 and 32 for K=100ğ¾100K=100. On the server side, we select 5 clients for aggregation per round when K=10ğ¾10K=10, and 10 clients per round when K=100ğ¾100K=100. This corresponds to a sampling rate of 50% for 10 clients (K=10ğ¾10K=10) and 10% for 100 clients (K=100ğ¾100K=100). The noise level in our experiments is ğ’©â€‹(0,0.15)ğ’©00.15\mathcal{N}(0,0.15). Appendix C Full Analysis on Information Theory Perspective

C.1 Features Partition

From an information theory perspective, we present formal definitions, namely DefinitionÂ 3.1 and DefinitionÂ 3.2, to define performance-robust features and performance-sensitive features. Specifically, DefinitionÂ 3.1 captures the desirable attributes when we partition the features, which are abstracted to be a variable in general. A valid partition should maintain all information of the original variable Xğ‘‹X losslessly. That is, neither extra information is introduced nor key information is lost. So we can get (i) and (ii) in DefinitionÂ 3.1. After determining the measure space, we partition the Xğ‘‹X to be X=X1+X2ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹2X=X_{1}+X_{2}. The mutual information of X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2} is none. Here, X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2} can be symmetric. Or saying, there is no overlap between X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1} and X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2}, as described by (iii) in DefinitionÂ 3.1.

Built upon the DefinitionÂ 3.1, we present the definition of performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features, as in DefinitionÂ 3.2. Intuitively, performance-sensitive features contain all label information, while performance-robust features contains all information about the data except for the label information. That is, the features to be partitioned are either performance-sensitive features or performance-robust features.

C.2 FedFed on Information Bottleneck Perspective

In this section, we analyse FedFed under an information bottleneck(IB) aspect. In conventional, information bottleneckÂ [21] can be formalized as:

Proof.

To get EqÂ (13), we firstly have:

Recall that DP-SGDÂ [27] samples i.i.d. noise from unbias Gaussian distribution ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,Sf2â€‹Ïƒ2)ğ’©0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†2ğ‘“superscriptğœ2\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},S^{2}_{f}\sigma^{2}), where Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f} is the sensitivity. This trick is motivated by cryptographic standard proof with ideal/real paradigmÂ [57]. For both ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} and ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}, the noise addition follows DP-SGDâ€™s idea, except for adding noise to the sampled data for updating gradients, rather than the latter-computed real gradients. We remark that this method works for FL but may be different for centralized training (with identical training set in the whole training process).

Using the property of post-processingÂ [16], the noise added to the data passes to (or projects to) the following gradient updates. Thus, for protecting training data in FL, we can attain TheoremÂ 3.3 to summarize the superiority of FedFed when asking for an identical privacy guarantee. TheoremÂ 3.3 explains the reason for the superior model performance of FedFed, which intrinsically boils down to a relatively small Ïƒğœ\sigma compared with sharing raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}.

D.2 Analysis and Proof for TheoremÂ 3.4

Previously, we showcase the view of each client for analyzing privacy. Albeit we do not aim at a new DP theorem, we expect a tighter privacy analysis for FedFed by using the advanced resultÂ [28]. Vadhan and WangÂ [58] prove that when the interactive mechanisms being composed are pure differentially private, their concurrent composition achieves privacy parameters (with respect to pure or approximate differential privacy) that match the (optimal) composition theorem for noninteractive differential privacy. To be specific, we follow the proof logic of TheoremÂ D.7Â [28] for analyzing globally shared data from all clients.

Given (Ïµk,Î´)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘˜ğ›¿(\epsilon_{k},\delta)-DP at each client side, we utilize the composition theorem to analyze overall privacy in FedFed. The concept of sensitivity below is originally used for sharing a dataset for achieving (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy.

Privacy loss is a random variable that accumulates the random noise added to the algorithm/model, which is utilized in TheoremÂ D.7.

Now, by LemmaÂ D.2, we get TheoremÂ 3.4 directly. In summary, FedFed protects two types of data features using two different protective manners, i.e., small noise for performance-sensitive features and extremely large noise for performance-robust features, and thus attains higher model performance and stronger security in the same time.

Appendix E More Results on Attack

E.1 More Details on Model Inversion Attack

In this section, we present additional results of the model inversion attack. When the central server assumes the role of the attacker without access to the original data, it exhibits a diminished performance in attacking the model. The raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} of FigureÂ 3 (a) and (b) can be found in FigureÂ 6(a). As we can see, ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} still causes privacy leakage and FigureÂ 6(b) also gives the intuitive necessity of DP protection on ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}.

Inspired by generative model inversion methodsÂ [40, 59], we conduct another experiment where one of the clients acts as the attacker. Similar to GMIÂ [40], the method involves leveraging an auxiliary dataset and a public dataset to launch an attack on the target model. In our experiments, we utilize the globally shared dataset as the auxiliary dataset, while the local private data serves as the public dataset because the client has access to its own local data. Under this scenario (results in FigureÂ 7), the attackerâ€™s performance is better than when the server acts as the attacker, while the attacker is still unable to recover data from the shared features. The model architectures of generative-based model inversion attack are listed in TableÂ 8.

E.2 More Details on Membership Inference Attack

Is TheoremÂ 3.3 true empirically?

Membership inference attack(MIA)Â [41, 15] attempts to infer whether a particular data point is in the target modelâ€™s training set.

Specifically, the global model on the server side can be regarded as the target model in FL. In our setting, we train a shadow model with globally shared data. Then the membership attack can be regarded as a binary classification task, member data or non-member data. The input of the attack model is the top-k vector of the output from the shadow model. To compare the superiority of sharing partial data rather than the complete data with DP, we conduct MIA to explore the divergence experimentally. Sharing raw data causes more information leakage (higher recall of MIA) than partial data with the same DP level. However, the FedFed needs a relatively small noise Ïƒğœ\sigma to achieve comparable protection. The attack process is shown in FigureÂ 8.

F.1 Visualization of Data Heterogeneity

We show the visualization of data distribution in FigureÂ 9. The LDA partition and the #â€‹C=2#ğ¶2\#C=2 partition have the label skew and the quantity skew simultaneously. And the Subset partition only has the label skew. #â€‹C=k#ğ¶ğ‘˜\#C=k means each client only has kğ‘˜k different labels from dataset, and kğ‘˜k controls the unbalanced degree. The subset method makes each client have all classes from the data, but one dominant class far away outnumbers other classes.

F.4 More experimental results

We provide more comparison results in this section to demonstrate the superiority of FedFed. FigureÂ 12, FigureÂ 13, FigureÂ 14, FigureÂ 15 have shown our enhancement in four datasets. In this paper, we mainly have four settings in our experiments: (1) Î±=0.1,E=1,K=10formulae-sequenceğ›¼0.1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğ¾10\alpha=0.1,E=1,K=10; (2) Î±=0.1,E=5,K=10formulae-sequenceğ›¼0.1formulae-sequenceğ¸5ğ¾10\alpha=0.1,E=5,K=10; (3) Î±=0.05,E=1,K=10formulae-sequenceğ›¼0.05formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğ¾10\alpha=0.05,E=1,K=10; (4) Î±=0.1,E=1,K=100formulae-sequenceğ›¼0.1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğ¾100\alpha=0.1,E=1,K=100.

In addition, we investigate the impact of varying sampling rates on the performance of our FL system, and present the results in TableÂ 9. We observe that increasing the sampling proportion leads to gradual improvements in the modelâ€™s performance, as well as faster convergence. This is due to a larger number of clients participating in each round, resulting in more consistent update directions for the aggregated model and the global model.

We also conduct tests on FedFed using various levels of heterogeneity, such as Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5 and Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1. The results are presented in TablesÂ 10 and Â 11. As the value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases, the original performance of FedAvg demonstrates significant improvement, while the performance enhancement of FedAvg deployed with FedFed is comparatively lower. This discrepancy can be attributed to the reduction in heterogeneity as Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases. When Î±ğ›¼\alpha reaches 1.0, the data distribution among clients becomes nearly homogeneous. As a result, the effectiveness of FedFed in mitigating heterogeneity through information sharing diminishes significantly.

F.5 More Results on Impact of DP noise

In this section, we present additional results on the impact of DP noise on three other datasets, as shown in FigureÂ 16. Our findings indicate that as the level of DP noise increases, the privacy budget decreases and the ability to protect information increases, but the performance of the model decreases accordingly. Thus, it is crucial to find a balance between privacy and performance in practical applications of our FedFed.

F.6 More Explanation: Performance-Sensitive Features vs. Performance-Robust Features

For an intuitive understanding of why there is no drastic performance degradation for utilizing ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} as a substitute for raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. Formally, e.g. in the classification task, a classifier trained by ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} gets comparable test accuracy on ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} giving the verification that ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} contains the primary features for generalization and vice versa. Specifically, three classifiers trained on ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}, and ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r}, Then test the generalization ability on ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r}, and ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}, separately. The result is shown in FigureÂ 17.

As described above, ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} extract from ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} in an IB manner contains more visual information about private data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} than ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}. To measure the visual similarity among performance-robust features ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r}, performance-sensitive features ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}, and raw data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. We choose PSNR [60, 61], prominent visual information comparisons of images, to calculate pixels error, the result is shown in TableÂ 12.

Consequently, higher PSNR denotes that ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} has the most visual information of ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} than ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s}. While ğ±rsubscriptğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{r} shares similarities with ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} in terms of its form or structure, it exhibits limitations that hinder its ability to enhance performance. At the same time, ğ±ssubscriptğ±ğ‘ \mathbf{x}_{s} has the commensurate generalization ability like ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} to achieve our goal.

F.7 Overheads Analysis of FedFed

For the extra computation induced by FedFed, we provide two views to demonstrate the limited costs of extra computation, i.e., training time and FLOPs.

TableÂ 14 shows that training a generator requires less than 10%percent1010\% of the time needed to train a classifier. Therefore, the additional training time required for the generator is limited.

TablesÂ 16 and 14 show the model complexity results, which indicate that the computation required for the generator is approximately 8.2%percent8.28.2\% of that required for the classifier. Additionally, the number of communication rounds needed for the generator is significantly lower than that required by the classifier, with only 15 rounds compared to 1000 rounds for the classifier (namely, Td=15subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘15T_{d}=15 and Tr=1000subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ1000T_{r}=1000).

The use of FedFed incurs additional memory usage, as the size of the globally-shared dataset is equivalent to the combined size of all clientsâ€™ data. This may have limited impacts on the bandwidth, as the generated data is only sent once. To quantitatively measure its effects, we compared the size of the dataset with that of the classifiers in TableÂ 16. Sharing the generated dataset is equivalent to sharing classifiers in multiple rounds. For example, for CIFAR10, the data requires approximately 586MB of memory, while the classifier requires about 48MB. Thus, sharing the global dataset requires the same amount of communication as sending a classifier in approximately 14 communication rounds.

Based on the aforementioned analysis, we provide a comprehensive examination of the communication overheads associated with the FedFed. Consider Kğ¾K clients in the FL system. Here, we detail two examples in our experiments:

    For K=10,Td=15formulae-sequenceğ¾10subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘15K=10,T_{d}=15, Tr=1000subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿ1000T_{r}=1000, and Î²=50%ğ›½percent50\beta=50\%, the extra communication costs are approximately 4.54%percent4.544.54\%.

To facilitate the further deployment of FedFed, we offer three strategies tailored to different storage hardware configurations:

  1. 1.

    One-time download: Local clients download the globally shared dataset once. A globally shared dataset costs approximately 14Ã—14\times the storage of a classifier model.

  2. 2.

    Partial download: A small portion of the globally shared dataset is selected and downloaded. This strategy incurs approximately 1.5Ã—1.5\times communication cost compared to the previous strategy, while the storage required by the clients is the same as that of local private data. This represents a storage-friendly choice that may involve a trade-off in terms of performance.

  3. 3.

    Intermittent download: A small set of globally shared dataset is downloaded after every Zğ‘Z rounds. This approach reduces the communication overhead to 1Z1ğ‘\frac{1}{Z} of that of strategy 2 while maintaining the storage overhead at the size of the local data.

Appendix G More Related Works

G.1 Federated Learning with Heterogeneous Data.

FL allows the distributed clients to train a model across multiple datasets jointly. It â€œprotectsâ€ user privacy by controlling data accessibility among different clients, i.e., only the data owner has the right to access the corresponding data. FedAvg [4] is the seminal work designed to reduce communication via more local training epochs and fewer communication rounds. In the following, many works [9, 5] observe that the FedAvgâ€™s divergence is considerable compared with centralized training if clients hold heterogeneous distribution. Even worse, the gap accumulates as the weight aggregates, potentially hurting model performance.

Recently, a series of works have tried to calibrate the updated direction of local training from the global model. FedProx [6] adds an L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} distance as the regularization term in the objective function, providing a theoretical guarantee of convergence. Similarly, FedIRÂ [42] operates on a mini-batch by self-normalized weights to address the non-identical class distribution. SCAFFOLDÂ [7] restricts the model using the previous knowledge. Besides, MOONÂ [43] introduces contrastive learning at the model level to correct the divergence between clients and the server.

Meanwhile, recent works propose designing new model aggregation schemes. FedAvgMÂ [33] performs momentum on the server side. FedNovaÂ [22] adopts a normalized averaging method to eliminate objective inconsistency. A studyÂ [66] also indicates that biasing client selection with higher local loss can speed up the convergence rate. The coordinate-wise averaging of weights also induces noxious performance. FedMAÂ [44] conducts a Bayesian non-parametric strategy for heterogeneous data. FedBNÂ [45] focuses on feature shift Non-IID and performs local batch normalization before averaging models.

Another existing direction for tackling data heterogeneity is sharing data. This line of work mainly assembles the data of different clients to construct a global IID dataset, mitigating client drift by replenishing the lack of information of clientsÂ [9]. Existing methods include synthesizing data based on the raw data by GANÂ [46]. However, the synthetic data is generally relatively similar to the raw data, leading to privacy leakage at some degree. Adding noise to the shared data is another promising strategyÂ [67, 68]. Some methods employ the statistics of dataÂ [48] to synthesize for sharing, which still contains some raw data content. Other methods distribute intermediate features [12], logits [49, 10], or learn the new embedding [50]. These tactics will increase the difficulty of privacy protection because some existing methods can reconstruct images based on feature inversion methodsÂ [51]. Most of the above methods share information without a privacy guarantee or with strong privacy-preserving but poor performance, posing the privacy-performance dilemma.

Concretely, in FDÂ [46] all clients leverage a generative model collaboratively for data generation in a homogeneous distribution. For better privacy protection, G-PATE [47] performs discriminators with local aggregation in GAN. Fed-ZDAC(Fed-ZDAS) [12], depending on which side to play augmentation, introduce zero-shot data augmentation by gathering intermediate activations and batch normalization(BN) statistics to generate fake data. Inspired by mixup data. Cronus [49] transmits the logits information while CCVR [10] collects statistical information of logits to sample fake data. FedFTG [64] use a generator to explore the input space of the local model and transfer local knowledge to the global model. FedDF [63] utilizes knowledge distillation based on unlabeled data or a generator and then conducts AVGLOGITS. We summarize existing information-sharing methods in TableÂ 17 to compare the dissimilarity with FedFed. The main difference between FedDF and FedFed is that our method distils raw data into two parts (performance-sensitive features xesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘’x_{e} and performance-robust features xrsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿx_{r}) rather than transferring distilled knowledge. We provide hierarchical protections to preserve information privacy while overcoming the privacy-performance dilemma.

G.2 Differential Privacy with Federated Learning

CarliniÂ et.alÂ [69] found that memorizing sensitive data occurs in early training, regardless of data rarity and model. Training with differential privacyÂ [70, 71] is a feasible solution to avoid its risk, albeit at some loss in utility. Differential privacy guarantees that an adversary should not discern whether a clientâ€™s data was used.

HuangÂ et alÂ [72] and WeiÂ et alÂ [73] are the first (to their knowledge) to analyze the relation between convergence and utility in FL. AndrewÂ et alÂ [74] explore setting an adaptive clipping norm in the federated setting rather than using a fixed one. AndrewÂ et alÂ [74] explore setting an adaptive clipping norm in the federated setting rather than using a fixed one. They show that adaptive clipping to gradients can perform as well as any fixed clip chosen by hand. HoevenÂ et alÂ [75] introduce data-dependent bounds and apply symmetric noise in online learning, which allows data providers to pick noise distribution. SunÂ et alÂ [76] explicitly vary ranges of weights at different layers in a DNN and shuffle high-dimensional parameters at an aggregation for easing explodes of privacy budgets. PengÂ et alÂ [77] study the knowledge embedding problem using DP protection in FL. Applying differential privacy and its variants to the federated setting become more prevailing nowadays.
